Mike,

I was wondering, what .ne file are you referring to for the DPNV 
settings?  My p2nv.ne file has both of those parameters set to 0.
The effect is then that genes only become disabled when a new node 
is added, and the only way such a gene can become reenabled is 
during a mating event:  if one of 2 matching genes is disabled 
during mating, there is a 25% chance it will be reenabled in the 
offspring.  However, neither of those two parameters were used, as 
far as I know.

Of course, whether or not they were used does not detract from the 
legitimacy of your question.  It is certainly still interesting the 
rate at which genes should be disabled or reinstated, and it is 
quite related to the work on pruning that e.g. Colin has been doing 
with SharpNEAT, or Derek and Philip have been doing with ANJI (these 
people are all in this group).  Although they use actual deletion 
operators, it is still related to disabling and the overall question 
of how much to simplify vs. complexify.  I'm not sure if you've seen 
any of their work in this area?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Mike Frayn" <redcrocodile@h...> wrote:
> Hello everyone,
> 
> Experienced programmer but very new to NEAT and to neuroevolution 
in 
> general.
> 
> So I'm working on a project that involves evolving a group of cat 
agents 
> that learn to successfully hunt an AI mouse in a pac-man style 
maze (line of 
> sight only).  Everything is going well so far.
> 
> However, I am curious to know everyone's thoughts about the two 
mutation 
> properties listed in the subject header.  I notice that Ken has 
them set at 
> 0.1 and 0.05 for the DPNV experiment and 0.0 for the rest.  I am 
using Mat 
> Buckland's WinNEAT and have added these two mutators to the code 
but am 
> unsure at how much to put their probabilities at.  10% seems like 
a lot for 
> disabling genes and then only 1/20 of the time will we re-enable 
one.
> 
> So I have two questions:
> 
> 1) Why so high for DPNV in particular?
> 2) What situations would you say that they are beneficial, when 
would they 
> not be too helpful?
> 
> My networks have 16 inputs and 5 outputs, they will end up being 
partially 
> recurrent.
> 
> Many thanks
> Mike
